close_symbols: NE_* flags (NE_none, NE_content_name, NE_content_type, NE_content_filename, NE_content_transfer_encoding)
explanation:
Why each symbol is required to check for invariant controlling expressions

- struct MHD_PostProcessor
  - The while and switch controlling expressions read and write many fields of pp (buffer_pos, buffer_size, skip_rn, state, dash_state, boundary/blen, nested_boundary/nlen, content_type, content_name, content_filename, content_transfer_encoding, have, value_offset, must_ikvi). You must know the exact layout and types of these fields (and whether any are volatile) to determine whether the expressions can change at runtime or are in fact invariant.

- enum PP_State (PP_* values)
  - The big switch uses pp->state as a controlling expression. To assess invariance you need the full set of PP_* values and their meaning so you can determine which functions and code paths can alter pp->state and whether some cases are constant for a particular invocation.

- enum RN_State (RN_* values)
  - The first switch uses pp->skip_rn. Knowing the RN_* enumerators and their semantics is necessary to understand which branches can be taken and whether skip_rn can be changed by code or subcalls (hence whether the switch/control is invariant).

- NE_* flags (NE_none, NE_content_name, NE_content_type, NE_content_filename, NE_content_transfer_encoding)
  - pp->have is used and mutated; its values are set/read across nested-state logic. Knowing these flags is required to understand whether parts of the state machine (and therefore controlling expressions) can change.

- find_boundary
  - This function is called from several PP_* states and can (by its contract/side effects) change pp->state, pp->buffer_pos/ioff, and other pp fields that appear in loop/switch conditions. To decide if the while condition or subsequent switches are invariant you must know whether find_boundary can modify those fields or return without changing them.

- process_multipart_headers
  - Called to parse headers; it can set pp->state, allocate/free or change content_type/content_* fields, set must_ikvi, and alter value_offset or other fields. Its side effects directly affect the controlling expressions (pp->state, nested handling) so its behavior must be known.

- process_value_to_boundary
  - This function advances through value content and on success/failure will alter pp->state, pp->buffer_pos/ioff, and/or other pp fields used in the while condition or subsequent switches. You must know its side effects to determine whether the while loop condition can change.

- free_unmarked
  - Although a cleanup function, it may modify pp fields (pp->have, allocated pointers) that influence later state-machine decisions. Knowledge of what free_unmarked touches is required to determine if later controlling expressions can change.

- MHD_str_equal_caseless_n_
  - Used in a conditional that can cause the state machine to take a nested-boundary path. While it probably does not mutate pp, you must know whether it has any side effects (or calls that do) and whether its result can be considered non-constant for the invocation (it depends on pp->content_type), affecting control flow decisions.

- MHD_post_process (caller / initializer)
  - The caller/initializer determines initial values of pp and possibly post_data_len. To determine whether any controlling expression in post_process_multipart is invariant for the invocation you need to know how pp was initialized (initial pp->state, skip_rn, buffer_pos, buffer_size, boundary/blen, content_type, nested_boundary, etc.) and how the caller calls this function (e.g., repeated calls with same pp).

(Notes)
- The above set focuses on symbols that can affect the runtime variability of the controlling expressions: the while condition and the switches on pp->skip_rn and pp->state. Standard library routines such as memcpy/memmove/strdup/strlen/free do not need separate listing here unless their behavior is wrapped/modified in this code base, because they do not change the logical control variables beyond their obvious effects described in the pp struct and the called functions.
